text: 12 oz bottle poured, with much thanks to Greg for the bottle! Always fun to try these beers that I would otherwise never come across. Near black tour, a thin tan fizz head. Quite true to the style, a dry, dusty chocolate constant. A slight metallic note in both the aroma and flavor, but not enough to bother me. Some coffee notes, but light. Chocolate remains the solo dominant character here. A soft dough. A solid addition to the style here. Enjoyed this brew.

Bottle in Seattle. Thanks Andrew! Dry bitter grain aroma. A slightly sweeter, brown sugar and lactic sip. Quite dark brown black body with dissipating tan foam. Nice dark nose. Great dry bitter body with a lactic backend. Lots of chocolate. This is nicely put together. Not bad.

$1.50 single 12floz bottle (BOD: 01.26.2017) to a nonic glass. Its black with a glittering brown head to bedazzle me. I sense some kind of wood aroma from the roasted malt, and dirt in the aroma too. I find this stout to be more slick than dry, and tastes like hickory and black twizzlers. I give it a firm ok.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of noted OT-Mer sethdude! Dark brown, thin foamy tan head, decent retention. Aroma of dry, roasted malt, dark chocolate, hints of mint. The taste is roasted malts, herbal hops. Thin-medium bodied, creamy, super dry, high carbonation. Nice.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a very dark black color with amber tints when held up to the light, a small white head. A nutty and roast nose. A nice roast, some dark fruit, light metallic roast (which I love), some vanilla. Quite drinkable. Very good. My kind of beer.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2016 Bottle pour into shaker pint glass. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee--a bit ashy--with hints of chocolate. Appearance is dark brown with effervescent sparkle, finger-width light brown fizzy, thin head with poor retention, light lacing. Taste is sweet, roasted malts with bitter coffee--a little too far toward the ash--with hints of dark fruits, chocolate. Palate is medium bodied with average texture and roasted/ashy, bitter finish with light fruit. Overall, this swings a little too far to the ashy side which dominates the experience.

Bottle from Greg (gregwilsonstl) -- cheers, buddy! This wears its straightforwardness like a badge of honor. No adjuncts, no coffee additions, just a classic, dark-malt-forward, dry stout. The result? One really nice, simple dry stout, with a malt sweetness and a hint of a roasted coffee bite, all on top of a thin, dry body. Very nice representation of the style.

Bottle. This has all the expected attributes, and well presented overall. Incredibly well bodied and fully flavored, rivaling many of the turbo-charged stouts out there, yet delivering a wallop of full-on roasted malt goodness. Delish. (#6213, 6/14/2016)

12 oz. bottle. Pitch black pour, with a small, tan, bubbly head. The nose is toast, black coffee, and light syrup and anise. Roasty and lightly sweet, with a low bitterness. Dry and fairly balanced. Light to medium body, chalky, a little acidic, with a clean, watery finish. This is a well-made and tasty stout. Just a little burnt, but not too off-putting. The palate is a little weak, but not too bad. Just a simple, easy stout.

Pours a dark brown color. Or maybe its ruby red, hard to tell. Nice beige head. Some retention, hardly any lacing.Aroma is deep toasted malt. Toasted not roasted. Espresso, not really any chocolate. Maybe cherry.Taste is mostly espresso, this has no coffee in it, so thats the toasted malts. I say toasted because, well, just tastes that way. Very malty and bittersweet. I taste no hops. Not so creamy like you would expect from a stout. It has this weird metallic taste at the end.Mouthfeel is medium heavy. Again that metallic taste is off putting. The metallic feel turns into the toasted malt flavor, which is odd.Overall, Im not a fan. The bottle says its from the St. James location, maybe thats the difference. But seriously, Guinness is much better. Im disappointed.

Bottle from gregwilsonstl, thanks for the opportunity! 
Dark brown with faint garnet at the edges, a smattering of off white bubbles grace the surface than quickly dissipate. Rich milk and dark chocolate notes dominate. Lightly fruity, lightly earthy. Fantastic stout, but much too sweet to be a dry stout. The carbonation is faint as well which may lead to a higher perception of sweetness.

This is very dark brown w/ a ring of white head. It has a big chocolate and roasted coffee nose. It is very lightly tart w/ a touch of sweetness. This has a nice solid roast character and a dry finish. It is medium bodied w/ slightly prickly carbonation.

12 oz. bottle from Craft Beer Cellar - Clayton. Pours a dark cocoa brown with a small tan head that fades into a ring. Very straightforward stout - roasted and toasted malts, a bit of earth, and thats pretty much it. Light-bodied, with moderate to medium carbonation. I hadnt even read the deScription here before pouring and rating this. But yeah, it doesnt carry the coffee-chocolate thing from other stouts. Its lovely in its simplicity.

Definitely a unique one. Very true to its dry stout nature with no coffee or chocolate flavors of note. Unfortunately this is to blame for its thin body and taste reminiscent of smoke and tobacco. Not bad, but similar to drinking charcoal if that was somehow remotely enjoyable.

Bottle, thanks mom! Rich roasted malt aroma with light chocolate as well. Pours black with a thin light brown head with good retention and lacing. Starts with rich roasted malt with a good medium body and smooth mouthfeel. Finishes smooth and dry with a bit chocolate before the roast comes back around and coats the palate. Excellent dry stout.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a good tan head that fades slowly with bit of lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, with just a hint of chocolate and coffee. taste of roasted malt, with just a trace of coffee. Nice bitterness and a dry finish. Full body, with a smooth and creamy. Very enjoyable stout, simple but good.

Tap/growler - fair size tan foamy head, almost pitch black color, good mildly roasty malt aroma and flavor, maybe just a little chocolate note in there, good hop balance, pretty good for a stout (not my usual favorite type) 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black with one finger head. Really pleasant sweet aroma. Chocolate malt, light coffee. Solid flavor, but finishes oddly sourish.

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to snifters, showing a ruby highlighted, brown color, with a presentable layer of brownish tan head foam, and spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was roasted, malty, and sweet caramel. Light bodied, with low carbonation, the taste was similar to the aroma, but a little washed out, flavor wise. Appreciated the simplicity, though.

The beer pours a clear dark reddish brown with a large tan head that persists somewhat. The aroma has lots of roasted and chocolate malts with a hint of smoke, and the taste is mildly umami, slightly bitter, and a touch sweet with roasted malts dominating the aftertaste. The palate fuses a thick texture, medium body, and a soft carbonation, but it is a tad too thin for the robust flavors.
Dry, chocolate, roasty, bready aroma. Flavor follows suit. Little bit of licorice. They really nailed this style. Not surprised this is in the tops for it on RB. Very nice beer.
Draft sampler pours black with a tan head. Aroma of malts, coffee and chocolate. Taste is coffee and malts

Tasted at the 2015 Centennial Beer Fest from bottle into sampler glass. It poured a clear dark reddish brown colour with weak beige foam. Bready and toasty, hint of coffee, VERY chocolatey, faint hops, faint fruity ale yeast esters. Good strength, good body. Tasty, though I wouldve called it a porter, no roasty notes at all.

Pour is a near black with a small tan head. Aroma is a decent roast and cocoa malt. Flavor is more of the same. Nice roasted malt with a cocoa power aftertaste. Finish is more cocoa with a bitter sweet chocolate. Nice stout and this brewers best beer IMO.

Pours brown with a reddish tint and has a tan head. The aroma has chocolate, smooth roast, hazelnuts, light coffee and a hint of woody malt. Really nice and comes across as a stout with some brown ale slant. It has a medium light body with a light amount of carbonation. The flavor starts with dark roasty malt with more of a bite than the aroma, dark chocolate, nuttiness, spicy / earthy hops and a touch of coffee bitterness. There is more of the coffee taste and hops on the finish and is really clean and nice. Solid stout.

Brown/black pour with tan head and lace. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. Flavor is sweet start with coffee, roasty, and a good malt bitter. Medium bodied but a touch fizzy for me. still solid

Growler... RBSG 2014 Cloudy dark-brown pour with a small, creamy, khaki head. Good retention. The nose is a lush mélange of roasted tree nuts, milk chocolate and vanilla. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and soft carbonation. The flavor is deep-roasted and acrid with tons of black mocha - Cuban espresso and an 85% cacao chocolate bar - in the finish. Really enjoyable.
Sampled at RBSG. From notes. Coffee and burnt malt dominate. Just a slight hint of caramel.
Sample from growler at SRBG Saturday tour 2014. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of malt, coffee, and chocolate, Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Enjoyable.

Growler @ RBSG brunch. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma. Roasted malty dry chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel finish.

Growler during RBSG 2014 at Schlafly Bottleworks brunch. Dark brownish black with tan head. Aromas of roast, dark fruit, chocolate. Tastes of roast, dark chocolate, light coffee. Medium-full body with a dry finish. Creamy mouthfeel.

Growler @ Brunch. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Roasted malt, some ash, and coffee grounds. Kind of nutty. A bit of acidic dark fruit. The flavor is a touch bitter and acidic. Roasted malt, cocoa powder, and lots of coffee grounds. Ok, I guess.

64oz growler tasted during RBSG grand tasting. Dark brown color. Thin off-white head. Leaves good bits and ropes of lace. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, chewy, lighter carbonation. Good moderate roasty dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, some light smoke. Lightly creamy texture. Moderate bitter, mild to moderate sweet. Awesome well-done flavorful stout.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2016 Updated rating 10/2016:  I usually dont rerate, but this is considerably better than the 2.6 I gave it 2 years ago.  Dry.  Cocoa powder.  Definitely not great, but better than my previous experience.   Previous rating 6/28/2014:  2.6 Dark black. Smells like chocolate. Very malty almost like extract. Milk chocolate.
Sampled at Schlafly during RBSG. Pours a black color with white head. Nice, burnt, roasty aromas. Nice roasty, coffee, burnt flavors. More pleasant than the other Public House beers.

This is very dark brown w/ a ring of white head. It has a big chocolate and roasted coffee nose. It is very lightly tart w/ a touch of sweetness. This has a nice solid roast character and a dry finish. It is medium bodied w/ slightly prickly carbonation. This is a pretty decent stout and the best by the brewery that I have so far tried.

Pour at the RBsG 2014 Schlafly Brunch (Maplewood, MO). Pours a deeper brownish black hue, good hazy middle with touches of cocoa and roast. Mellow coffee and biscuit, not sweet but dry, firmly bitter and roasty, kiss of caramel. Initial is medium bodied, a decent bitterness with firmer roast, carmelized malts, toast and some gentle kiss of toffee. A bit of brown malt, earthiness and cocoa. Middle is a touch sweet, gentle girhth that tapers out a bit more. Decent carmelized and roast feels on the backend, cold coffee and toasty biscuits. Some caramel, more cocoa nib and flashes of earth, bit of sweetness in toffee, roast and gentle coffee hit on the palate. Finish is dry, carmelized, good lingering flavors.

Sampled from a growler at RBSG 2014. Pours near black with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has light roasted malt with dark grain and a bit of dryness. Flavor has dry roasted malts through out with some earthy dark grains.
Nose is strong coffee with a green coffee bean almost vegetal note. Taste is slightly astringent and overly roasty with a very thin and watery mouthfeel. Not much else going on, very plain.

Thanks to LuckyDog for bringing back a a growler. Rated from recent memory - Ive got to find my notes. Dry and nutty, slight sour notes in the flavor and the aroma. Usual stout darkness, non-viscous pour. Dark cocoa. @ Friday meeting. Enjoyable.
Sampled at MO Beer Fest. Black and substantial looking. A roasted coffee aroma with somechocolate. Coffee is tasted and is out front. Only a little fitrus. The feel is just a bit thin. Nice, though.

Draught at the Public House Brewing Co, Rolla, MO. 
Dark reddish brown almost black colour with a small white head.
Roasted malt, coffee, mild bitterness and some dark chocolate in the aroma. 
The flavour is coffee... big time. There's some roasted malt, sweetness (that cuts the coffee well) and mild bitterness. Thin but not watery. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

GABF 2012 
Appearance: Black with a small beige head 
Aroma and flavors of roasted malts, light smokiness and coffee 
Ok, thin mouthfeel.

Tap at the brewery in Rolla. Poured a jet black color with a rich creamy tan head. Aroma was nutty, roasted malts, hops and chocolate. Very toasty and dry. Hops in the finish. Milk chocolate taste. Very good beer.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of roasted/charred malt, bitter chocolate. Flavor is definitely dry, roasted and charred malt. Great dry palate with little sweetness. Very easy drinking. The palate is robust but not heavy (has the feel of a 7% abv, not in terms of alcohol flavors just robustness, though its only 5%). Yum!
7/4/8/5/15 (3.9/5)

Overall, one of the better draft stouts I have had. A very clean but robust tast, hints of chocolate flow through this beer. This is a great rendintion fo the style, not to bitter, not to strong just right.
Growler shared thanks to Jarrett. Slightly smokey. Dry stout with decent body. Not heavy. Some chocolate. Lowe carbonation out of growler. Enjoyable.

The pour is all black with a nice khaki head. The aroma is coffee and roasted malt. The flavor is more of the coffee roast, though not quite as pronounced as the nose. After a few sips, the roastiness fades, and it is a pretty basic, though highly drinkable stout. A bit thin on the palate. Highlight was the aroma, which was nice.  A very decent stout overall.
